title-part.text: CONJOINT CONTROL OF VEHICLE SUB-UNITS OF DIFFERENT TYPE OR DIFFERENT FUNCTION
CONTROL SYSTEMS SPECIALLY ADAPTED FOR HYBRID VEHICLES
ROAD VEHICLE DRIVE CONTROL SYSTEMS FOR PURPOSES NOT RELATED TO THE CONTROL OF A PARTICULAR SUB-UNIT
Conjoint control of vehicle sub-units of different type or different function

reference.text: for propulsion of purely electrically-propelled vehicles with power supplied within the vehicle B60L11/00

note.note-paragraph: When classifying in this group, each controlled sub-unit must be separately identified by a classification in a relevant place in this group.

CPC-specific-text.text: Clutches for bridging a fluid gearing, e.g. lock-up

title-part.text: including control of electric propulsion units, e.g. motors or generators
with separate change-speed gear trains arranged in series
with two input flow paths, e.g. double clutch transmission selection of one of the torque flow paths by the corresponding input clutch
including control of all-wheel-driveline means, e.g. transfer gears or clutches for dividing torque between front and rear axle
Central differentials for dividing torque between front and rear axles
Axle differentials, e.g. for dividing torque between left and right wheels

this group is not complete pending a reorganisation, see also B60W10/184

title-part.text: acting within the driveline, e.g. retarders
including control of energy storage means
for electrical energy, e.g. batteries or capacitors
including control of auxiliary equipment, e.g. air-conditioning compressors or oil pumps

Control systems specially adapted for hybrid vehicles, i.e. vehicles having two or more prime movers of more than one type, e.g. electrical and internal combustion motors, all used for propulsion of the vehicle

note.note-paragraph: Classification is also made in B60K6/04 for the different types of hybrid electric vehicles

CPC-specific-text.text: controlling the power contribution of each of the prime movers to meet required power demand

title-part.text: strategies, i.e. control methods based on models predicting performance]

in order to stay within battery power input and output limits or to prevent overcharging or over-discharging
Special control strategies to achieve a particular effect

Control strategies including selection of transmission gear ratio
controlling the transition between prime movers, i.e. engaging or disengaging a prime mover
Control strategies for fault diagnosis, failsafe operation or limp home mode

title-part.text: Purposes of road vehicle drive control systems not related to the control of a particular sub-unit, e.g. of systems using conjoint control of vehicle sub-units,

title-part.text: predicting or avoiding probable or impending collision

CPC-specific-text.text: or attempting to minimise its consequences

Taking automatic action to avoid collision, e.g. braking and steering

the prediction being responsive to traffic or environmental parameters

title-part.text: Control of distance between vehicles, e.g. keeping a distance to preceding vehicle
Automatically following the path of a preceding lead vehicle, e.g. "electronic tow-bar"
with provision for special action when the preceding vehicle comes to a halt, e.g. stop and go

Rocking, i.e. fast change between forward and reverse
at stand still, e.g. engine in idling state

Selecting between different operative modes, e.g. comfort and performance modes

title-part.text: excessive wear or burn out of friction elements, e.g. clutches

related to low temperature conditions, e.g. high viscosity of hydraulic fluid

Fixing failures by repairing failed parts, e.g. loosening a sticking valve

Limiting the input power, torque or speed
Monitoring the functioning of the control system

Tactile feedback to the driver, e.g. vibration or force feedback to the driver on the steering wheel or the accelerator pedal

title-part.text: Automatic control, details of type of controller or control system architecture
In analogue systems, e.g. continuous systems
In digital systems, e.g. discrete-time systems involving sampling
Processor details or data handling, e.g. memory registers or chip architecture
Feedback, closed loop systems or details of feedback error signal
Modal analysis, e.g. for determining system stability
Method for the design of a control system
Control system elements or transfer functions
Gains, weighting coefficients or weighting functions
Quarter vehicle model, i.e. only one vehicle corner
Single-track, 2D vehicle model, i.e. two-wheel bicycle model
Multiple-track, 2D vehicle model, e.g. four-wheel model
Multiple-track, 3D vehicle model, e.g. including roll and pitch conditions
Multiple-track, 3D multi-body vehicle model, e.g. combination of models for vehicle sub-units
Signal treatments, identification of variables or parameters, parameter estimation or state estimation
Cut-off filters, retarders, delaying means, dead zones, threshold values or cut-off frequency
Frequency analysis, spectral techniques or transforms
Manual parameter input, manual setting means, manual initialising or calibrating means

title-part.text: using a remote, e.g. cordless, transmitter or receiver unit, e.g. remote keypad or mobile phone

using buttons or a keyboard connected to the on-board processor
Giving intention of direction, e.g. by indicator lights, steering input
Switching between manual and automatic parameter input, and vice versa
Controller asks driver to take over
Driver shifts control to the controller, e.g. by pressing a button

involving external transmission of data to or from the vehicle
using data transmitted between vehicles, e.g. for platooning, control of inter-vehicle distance

Resetting start and end points of actuator travel
Historical data record of previous events
